Posts.Content: Hi everyone. Had my first of 6 (3weekly) chemo on Wednesday. Decided to go with the cold cap as I don't want sparse hair/baldness to be the first thing people notice about me.  However... I found the experience horrendous! I do suffer from tension headaches a lot so this may have made it worse. Felt like my head was in a vice and for the last hour I struggled to hold back the tears. I had been determined to approach chemo positively but feel the cold cap undermined that. Telling myself I should give it another go for cycle 2 but realistically I also feel that I don't need the extra stress. Most other people seem to have managed it and I am feeling a bit of a wimp.
Posts.Title: Any thoughts on the cap to avoid hair falling out?

Posts.Content: My mum is an endless source of ill advised comments. "You have some colour in your cheeks today - better than last week;you looked awful then" "Now you have no hair, you look like your dad." " "You look like Uncle xxx now - I think it is your eyes." (Uncle xxx was bald for as long back as I can remember and sadly died last year quite soon after being diagnosed with cancer - thanks for the reminder mum). Good job we always take her with a pinch of salt. She is very supportive when she takes her foot out of her mouth. Most annoying are those work colleagues who told me they had had BC and were up for a chat about their experience. Not helpful, I'm struggling through my own, don't want to hear about yours, thanks.
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Hi Butterfly baby - welcome!  I had my 4th EC last Wednesday and have 2 more to ho before having radiotherapy. Just taking one treatment at a time so focussing on the here and now of chemo. Side effects do seem to differ vastly from person to person.  I haven't been sick, nausea felt much like that I suffered when pregnant. I have terrible heartburn though - it seems to come for a couple of days at a time, disappear and then rear its ugly head a few days later. Suffered with sleeplessness, especially when taking steroids. Seems to have been worse this time and I have been a bit demented during the day! Tiredness/fatigue has got progressively worse with each treatment but I have managed to work during week 3 of each cycle on reduced hours. Haven't had a day yet when I didn't go out of house, although I was close yesterday. Hair: did cold cap first 3 treatments but not after that as I found it a bit too traumatic. Hair just about gone now (everywhere!) But I have a wig and hats. Overall not as bad as I expected, so far, staying positive and looking forward to getting a step closer to having my life back.
Posts.Title: June 2017 Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Glad you feel all went well Jojo4. The main hurdle I felt had to overcome was listening to my body - I don't usually have time off work and the balance of taking care of my self while not wallowing in self pity was something I have had to work at.  As far as the scar/look of the boob is concerned, you will definitely see changes over the weeks following the op so when you do brave a look, think of it as a work in progress. Keep looking after yourself. X
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: Hi Jillybean I’m adding another welcome. I joined this group early on after my diagnosis when I was living on google trying to find information about what was going to happen to me.  I don’t post much but follow lots and at times this forum has been a godsend. I was diagnosed after finding a lump in my breast. My first mammogram three months earlier had found nothing (I’m 50 too). I had a lumpectomy, chemo and finished radiotherapy just over two weeks ago. I can say it has been a real roller coaster ride so far! My advice to you at this point is take one step at a time. Focus on your operation and recovering from that first. Be kind to yourself and accept help, especially with practical/physical stuff from anyone who offers. Hugs for you for next week. Xx
Posts.Title: Recently been diagnosed, looking for support through my journey.

Posts.Content: Hi Gay.  Thanks for your reply. There is a big square dressing where the line goes into my arm. There is a piece of line below the dressing with a plastic clamp then a stopper at the end. That part is not taped down - when I'm laid or resting the arm on something those bits poke into my skin. The tights idea sounds great and have lots of unused patterned tights. Didn't want to have to buy anything as I'm trying to watch the pennies. ☺
Posts.Title: PICC line - advice please

Posts.Content: Hi everyone. Had as PICC line put in on Thursday (veins had gone into hiding and arm swollen and painful from elbow down). Was given a couple of fine mesh sleeves with the instruction to wear at night and in day if needed depending on clothing. Am putting cotton wool pads under clamp and stopped at end as the sleeve pushes them into my skin. Just wondering what else I can use to cover up at night. The fine mesh leaves a pattern on my skin (even though it's not night) and I think it is going yo make my skin sore. Was thinking tubigrip but hubby says will be tii tight. What have others used? Suggestions will be greatly appreciated.  ☺
Posts.Title: PICC line - advice please

Posts.Content: Thank you all so much for your replies everyone. I am so glad I joined this forum. Not only was it the first port if call for me when I realised I had a problem, but it is so uplifting to read the support that everyone gets/gives on a daily basis. I have shifted to tights (actually pop socks with the toe cut off). So comfortable and less obtrusive, although I find I don't care about the line being visible. Had pre chemo blood tests today -heaven; no needles! Dressing changed & cleaned - not so heavenly as the entry site is a bit red & sore. Nurse took a swab & I have to keep a close eye on it & temp. Not too worried though as I'm back for cycle 4 of chemo tomorrow so they will check it again. Hope everyone gets some sleep tonight or at least finds something good to watch on telly.
Posts.Title: PICC line - advice please

Posts.Content: Bless you Ossy, you did have treatment - a mastectomy is difficult to have to deal with. Even if you hadn't the whole experience of scans, biopsies etc is difficult to tho through. I think the most difficult thing to deal with is having no control, especially when as mums we organise, control and take caste of so much for our families. As others have said, ask to speak to a counsellor. A friend if mine found it so helpful. Sending big hugs and sunshine.
Posts.Title: Just feel like crying all the time

Posts.Content: I had PICC line put in after 3 cycles due to arm swelling and veins disappearing out of sight. Never had bp taken on PICC arm, it was done on other arm (had one lymph node removed) with no problems. This seemed to be common practice...
Posts.Title: Blood pressure cuff and PICC line

Posts.Content: I'm glad to see these posts as I often feel I'm the only one going all 'baa humbug'.  Lost most of my hair after cycle 2 so asked my oldest daughter to shave the rest. Hubby was a mess emotionally and     I did my best to hold it together for the sake of my daughters.  Being bald was very difficult at first. As others have said I didn't see myself in the mirror and hated that people who saw me out in my various hats could work out I had cancer. I'm a very private person and I felt like I might as well be carrying a banner.  My oldest daughter said she would shave hers too and I said absolutely not! Fast forward to now and I recognise the lady in the mirror- its still me! Most of the time enjoying rocking the hats. Don't mind kids staring or asking 'where's your hair?' Do mind adults staring- want  to shout 'get a grip! Haven't you seen a bald 51 year old in a trilby before?' Hubby has progressed from hating the bald head as it reminded him what I was going through to telling me yesterday that it didn't even register with him anymore as I just looked like me. Bless! As well as the numerous ads for charity campaigns connected with cancer, it seems that every soap or drama has to have a cancer storyline. We do joke about it in our house but it shows great insensitivity by writers. Surely they can find other things to dramatise. Do, no to shaving- do something fun instead. And Macmillan, listen to those who are/have lived this nightmare. Rant over.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone. Well, I’m in a flap. I’m just over 1 year since diagnosis of Grade 3 invasive BC and WLE - sentinel node removed but no node involvement. I also had 6 cycles of EC chemo followed by 15 rads and 5 boosts ‘because it was so aggressive’.  I’ve been back at work since September, I’m tired but been getting on with life. I had my first mammogram following treatment last Friday. Tried not to read into what radiographer said and spent the weekend telling myself it’s all good. However, I had a missed call from the hospital number about lunchtime (didn’t see it until about 4.30). When I called the number back, it was just a recorded message saying it was xxx hospital trust and they would call back if necessary.  Didn’t have BCN number at work with me so couldn’t call that team. So scared now that they are recalling me already but also damn angry at one attempted ‘phone call from them and no other attempt. Doesn’t someone realise how anxious that makes someone, how stressful that is?
Posts.Title: First annual mammogram

Posts.Content: Thank you for your kind words Leolady56. I’m going to try to sleep- whatever happens I need to go to work in the morning. As you suggest, if not I will peep into ‘Awake’. I stopped following the thread a couple of months ago as the notifications were clogging up my email!  This blooming disease has turned me from optimist to pessimist but you are right ‘que sera sera’.  Will ‘phone the BCNs first thing in the morning and as you say will be up and fighting whatever.  Keeping the missed call news  under my hat and away from hubby for now though. Let’s see what tomorrow brings before sharing...
Posts.Title: First annual mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi Undergroundbarbie. Glad you didn’t need any other treatment after your WLE. I had my WLE end of Feb 2017. Surgeon explained everything and I think I went in with the understanding it was not a minor op. My lump was about 3cm and he explained that once they have removed it and the margins, the surgeon ‘frees up’ surrounding tissue in the hope it will give a better cosmetic result in the long term.  I had another check up this week and told the surgeon about the pains (as others have described), sometimes mild but sometimes excruciating. He said it is still early days for recovery especially as I then had chemo & rads.  Hopefully you will see/feel improvement over time.

Posts.Content: Thanks for the link crystaljuju. It is really useful. I did think the strawberry/raspberry thing was random.  Strawbs on my shopping list for tomorrow!
Posts.Title: Diet while on chemo - what to avoid?

Posts.Content: Hi Mazza10. I would say don't be worried about the PICC line. I had 3 cycles of EC via cannula (plus blood tests day before). Cycles 1 & 2 went in no problem. However between cycles 2 & 3 my arm swelled up like a sausage and veins were virtually invisible! Blood test day before cycle 3 took 4 attempts to find vein. For chemo, took nurse two attempts and I was a mess. Senior nurse on chemo ward suggested a PICC line - talked me through procedure, gave me leaflet to read and they arranged it for me there and then. It was odd at first having such as visible reminder of what was happening to me but I got quite quickly to the point where I just don't care who sees it or what they think. Mostly I wear a mesh cover but just to keep it under control and not flap about; wear long sleeves to work but only because I'm being 'professional me' and don't want to invite any comments etc. If I ever had to go through this again (god forbid) I would ask for a PICC from the off as my sausage arm is still sore and I will def need physio afterwards.
Posts.Title: Blood Clot in PICC line

Posts.Content: Thanks dreamthief - your explanation of the 'flash frying' makes a lot of sense.  I am getting the hang of what to eat for optimum taste: bland stuff like honeydew melon is a definite no no for me. Unfortunately sweet stuff tastes as amazing as it ever did.
Posts.Title: Diet while on chemo - what to avoid?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone.  I am currently in the middle of chemo: had 2nd of 6 EC following WLE/sentinel lymph node removal with diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma. I have read around what not to eat to try to prevent picking up a food related infection. I understand to basically avoid foods that pregnant ladies would avoid. I was told by breast cancer nurse to not eat raspberries or strawberries as they can harbour germs in their skins but haven't read this anywhere so not sure that this is 'official' advice. Also eating out - was definitely told by someone to not eat out at all but again haven't read this specific advice anywhere. So, just looking for clarification. Don't wan't to do anything risky but I do love raspberries (and they are sooooo healthy) and eating out was one of mine and hubbies guilty pleasures.
Posts.Title: Diet while on chemo - what to avoid?

Posts.Content: Hi Sharmer, as others have said sorry you have joined this club. That said it has been a great reassurance to me to read about other people's experiences. Also some funny and uplifting tales. Always hugs galore too! I understand you wanting to go to next appointment alone and tell children after. I took hubby, only because he insisted - I was more worried about how he was feeling than myself!  Take care of yourself and don't be too hard on yourself if you to shed a few tears. Hugs.
Posts.Title: ... started my journey today

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass. I was the same yesterday but as the day progressed got more and more teary. Not giant boo hoos just leaky eyes that kept catching me out.  Glad you are more up today. Here's a hug either way (())
Posts.Title: Feelings.......

Posts.Content: Hi Emma, I’ve been on Tamoxifen since August 2017. Horrendous sweats continue day and night, in spite of change of brand about 2 months ago. I took Clonidine on advice of Oncologist but have just stopped taking it. It had a small impact on the sweats but gave me itchy skin, leg and foot cramps and restless legs at night.  I hope you find some respite soon.
Posts.Title: tamoxifen - hot flushes

Posts.Content: I’m in agreement with Newdawn; everyone needs to tell in their own way. I found a lump and didn’t even tell hubby until I had date for hospital (told my boss then too). Only us knew until I had seen surgeon and knew what the plan was. We then told immediate family my mum & Dad and our children. Word spread around wider family. I had asked my boss not to tell folk at work why I was absent but in run up to op I realised they needed to know.  As for other friends, I’ve told them as I’ve seen them and that has been ok. I’m not one to make a fuss and have mainly managed without tears! Never posted on Fb about treatment etc - it just never felt right to me. I did  a group of ex colleagues who I knew I wouldn’t see for s while. I knew that they would want to know & express their support. I’m sure everyone does it differently and it never is easy as we are always worrying about other people’s feelings. Do what feels right to you.
Posts.Title: How to tell friends?

Posts.Content: I have been taking Tamoxifen since August. Major hot (and cold) flushes as well as sleepless nights. Have knee & back pain but have had bad back for a long time now. Seeing physio next week. Oncologist said it can take up to a year for side effects to settle down. She recommended going to The Haven in Leeds to try to get some alternative therapies.
